abstract.p: Letter from Donald J Boudreax (Foundation for Economic Education) on Bob Herbert's Sept 4 column says most workers who work longer hours do so voluntarily, to earn more

block.p: In his Sept. 4 column, Bob Herbert correctly reports that the last few years have witnessed a significant rise in the inflation-adjusted wages of nearly all Americans. Mr. Herbert then laments the fact that the amount of time today's workers spend working has also risen.

In his Sept. 4 column, Bob Herbert correctly reports that the last few years have witnessed a significant rise in the inflation-adjusted wages of nearly all Americans. Mr. Herbert then laments the fact that the amount of time today's workers spend working has also risen.

Why the lament? When wages are higher, even workers who choose not to work longer hours take home more pay. Most workers who do work longer hours do so voluntarily, drawn by the ability to earn more for each extra hour worked, not because economic necessity drives them to work longer.
DONALD J. BOUDREAX Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y. Sept. 4, 2000
The writer is president of the Foundation for Economic Education.
